016package tech.uom.seshat;
017
018import java.util.OptionalInt;
019import javax.measure.Dimension;
020import javax.measure.Unit;
021import javax.measure.UnitConverter;
022import javax.measure.format.ParserException;
023import javax.measure.Quantity;
024import javax.measure.quantity.*;
025import tech.uom.seshat.resources.Errors;
026
027import static tech.uom.seshat.UnitRegistry.SI;
028import static tech.uom.seshat.UnitRegistry.ACCEPTED;
029import static tech.uom.seshat.UnitRegistry.IMPERIAL;
030import static tech.uom.seshat.UnitRegistry.OTHER;
031import static tech.uom.seshat.UnitRegistry.PREFIXABLE;
032
033
034/**
035 * Provides constants for various Units of Measurement together with static methods working on {@link Unit} instances.
036 * Unit names and definitions in this class follow the definitions provided in the EPSG geodetic dataset
037 * (when the unit exists in that dataset),
038 * except “year” which has been renamed “{@linkplain #TROPICAL_YEAR tropical year}”.
039 * This class focuses on the most commonly used units in the geospatial domain:
040 * angular units ({@linkplain #DEGREE degree}, {@linkplain #ARC_SECOND arc-second}, …),
041 * linear units ({@linkplain #KILOMETRE kilometre}, {@linkplain #NAUTICAL_MILE nautical mile}, …) and
042 * temporal units ({@linkplain #DAY day}, {@linkplain #TROPICAL_YEAR year}, …),
043 * but some other kind of units are also provided for completeness.
044 * The main quantities are listed below, together with some related units:
045 *
046 * <table class="sis">
047 *   <caption>Some quantities and related units</caption>
048 *   <tr><th colspan="2">Quantity type</th><th>System unit</th><th>Some conventional units</th></tr>
049 *
050 *   <tr><td style="padding-top:15px" colspan="4"><b>Fundamental:</b></td></tr>
051 *   <tr><td>{@link Length}</td>            <td>(L)</td> <td>{@link #METRE}</td>    <td>{@link #CENTIMETRE}, {@link #KILOMETRE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #FOOT}</td></tr>
052 *   <tr><td>{@link Mass}</td>              <td>(M)</td> <td>{@link #KILOGRAM}</td> <td></td></tr>
053 *   <tr><td>{@link Time}</td>              <td>(T)</td> <td>{@link #SECOND}</td>   <td>{@link #MILLISECOND}, {@link #MINUTE}, {@link #HOUR}, {@link #DAY}, {@link #WEEK}, {@link #TROPICAL_YEAR}</td></tr>
054 *   <tr><td>{@link ElectricCurrent}</td>   <td>(I)</td> <td>{@link #AMPERE}</td>   <td></td></tr>
055 *   <tr><td>{@link Temperature}</td>       <td>(Θ)</td> <td>{@link #KELVIN}</td>   <td>{@link #CELSIUS}, {@link #FAHRENHEIT}</td></tr>
056 *   <tr><td>{@link AmountOfSubstance}</td> <td>(N)</td> <td>{@link #MOLE}</td>     <td></td></tr>
057 *   <tr><td>{@link LuminousIntensity}</td> <td>(J)</td> <td>{@link #CANDELA}</td>  <td></td></tr>
058 *
059 *   <tr><td style="padding-top:15px" colspan="4"><b>Dimensionless:</b></td></tr>
060 *   <tr><td>{@link Angle}</td>      <td></td> <td>{@link #RADIAN}</td>    <td>{@link #DEGREE}, {@link #ARC_MINUTE}, {@link #ARC_SECOND}, {@link #GRAD}</td></tr>
061 *   <tr><td>{@link SolidAngle}</td> <td></td> <td>{@link #STERADIAN}</td> <td></td></tr>
062 *
063 *   <tr><td style="padding-top:15px" colspan="4"><b>Derived:</b></td></tr>
064 *   <tr><td>{@link Area}</td>     <td>(A)</td> <td>{@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td>      <td>{@link #HECTARE}</td></tr>
065 *   <tr><td>{@link Volume}</td>   <td>(V)</td> <td>{@link #CUBIC_METRE}</td>       <td></td></tr>
066 *   <tr><td>{@link Speed}</td>    <td>(ν)</td> <td>{@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}</td> <td>{@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}</td></tr>
067 *   <tr><td>{@link Pressure}</td> <td></td>    <td>{@link #PASCAL}</td>            <td>{@link #HECTOPASCAL}, {@link #DECIBAR}, {@link #BAR}, {@link #ATMOSPHERE}</td></tr>
068 * </table>
069 *
070 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (IRD, Geomatys)
071 * @version 1.1
072 * @since   1.0
073 */
074public final class Units {
075    /**
076     * Unit of measurement defined as 10<sup>-9</sup> metres (1 nm).
077     * This unit is often used in wavelength measurements.
078     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
079     * and the unlocalized name is "nanometre".
080     *
081     * <div class="note">
082     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
083     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
084     *   <tr><td>SI units:</td>         <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code NANOMETRE}</u>, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
085     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
086     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
087     * </table></div>
088     */
089    public static final Unit<Length> NANOMETRE;
090
091    /**
092     * Unit of measurement defined as 0.001 metres (1 mm).
093     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE},
094     * the unlocalized name is “millimetre” and the identifier is EPSG:1025.
095     *
096     * <div class="note">
097     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
098     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
099     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, <u>{@code MILLIMETRE}</u>, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
100     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
101     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
102     * </table></div>
103     */
104    public static final Unit<Length> MILLIMETRE;
105
106    /**
107     * Unit of measurement defined as 0.01 metres (1 cm).
108     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE},
109     * the unlocalized name is “centimetre” and the identifier is EPSG:1033.
110     *
111     * <div class="note">
112     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
113     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
114     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, <u>{@code CENTIMETRE}</u>, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
115     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
116     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
117     * </table></div>
118     */
119    public static final Unit<Length> CENTIMETRE;
120
121    /**
122     * The SI base unit for distances (m).
123     * The unlocalized name is “metre” and the identifier is EPSG:9001.
124     * This is the base of all other {@linkplain #isLinear(Unit) linear} units.
125     *
126     * <div class="note">
127     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
128     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
129     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <u><b>{@code METRE}</b></u>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
130     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
131     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
132     * </table></div>
133     */
134    public static final Unit<Length> METRE;
135
136    /**
137     * Unit of measurement defined as 1000 metres (1 km).
138     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE},
139     * the unlocalized name is “kilometre” and the identifier is EPSG:9036.
140     *
141     * <div class="note">
142     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
143     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
144     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, <u>{@code KILOMETRE}</u>.</td></tr>
145     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
146     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}.</td></tr>
147     * </table></div>
148     */
149    public static final Unit<Length> KILOMETRE;
150
151    /**
152     * Unit of measurement defined as exactly 1852 metres (1 M).
153     * This is approximately the distance between two parallels of latitude
154     * separated by one {@linkplain #ARC_MINUTE arc-minute}.
155     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE},
156     * the unlocalized name is “nautical mile” and the identifier is EPSG:9030.
157     *
158     * <p>There is no internationally agreed symbol for nautical mile. Seshat uses “M” in agreement with the
159     * International Hydrographic Organization (IHO) and the International Bureau of Weights and Measures (BIPM).
160     * But “NM” and “nmi” are also in use.</p>
161     *
162     * <div class="note">
163     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
164     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
165     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
166     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, <u>{@code NAUTICAL_MILE}</u>.</td></tr>
167     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}.</td></tr>
168     * </table></div>
169     */
170    public static final Unit<Length> NAUTICAL_MILE;
171
172    /**
173     * Unit of measurement defined as exactly 1609.344 metres (1 mi).
174     * This unit is often named “mile” without qualifier, but Seshat uses “statute mile”
175     * for emphasing the difference with {@linkplain #NAUTICAL_MILE nautical mile}.
176     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}.
177     * The unlocalized name is “statute mile” but is localized as "international mile" in the US
178     * for avoiding confusion with the US survey mile.
179     * The identifier is EPSG:9093.
180     *
181     * <div class="note">
182     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
183     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
184     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
185     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, <u>{@code STATUTE_MILE}</u>, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
186     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}.</td></tr>
187     * </table></div>
188     */
189    public static final Unit<Length> STATUTE_MILE;
190
191    /**
192     * Unit of measurement approximately equals to 0.3048006096… metres.
193     * The legal definition is exactly 12/39.37 metres.
194     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE},
195     * the unlocalized name is “US survey foot” and the identifier is EPSG:9003.
196     *
197     * <div class="note">
198     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
199     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
200     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
201     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, <u>{@code US_SURVEY_FOOT}</u>, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
202     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
203     * </table></div>
204     */
205    public static final Unit<Length> US_SURVEY_FOOT;
206
207    /**
208     * Unit of measurement defined as 0.3047972654 metres.
209     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE},
210     * the unlocalized name is “Clarke’s foot” and the identifier is EPSG:9005.
211     *
212     * <div class="note">
213     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
214     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
215     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
216     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, <u>{@code CLARKE_FOOT}</u>, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
217     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
218     * </table></div>
219     */
220    public static final Unit<Length> CLARKE_FOOT;
221
222    /**
223     * Unit of measurement defined as exactly 0.3048 metres (1 ft).
224     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE},
225     * the unlocalized name is “foot” and the identifier is EPSG:9002.
226     *
227     * <div class="note">
228     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
229     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
230     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
231     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, <u>{@code FOOT}</u>, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
232     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
233     * </table></div>
234     */
235    public static final Unit<Length> FOOT;
236
237    /**
238     * Unit of measurement defined as 2.54 centimetres (1 in).
239     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
240     * and the unlocalized name is “inch”.
241     *
242     * <div class="note">
243     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
244     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
245     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
246     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, <u>{@code INCH}</u>, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
247     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
248     * </table></div>
249     */
250    public static final Unit<Length> INCH;
251
252    /**
253     * Unit of measurement defined as 0.013837 inch (1 pt).
254     * This is commonly used to measure the height of a font.
255     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
256     * and the unlocalized name is “point”.
257     *
258     * <div class="note">
259     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
260     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
261     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
262     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code POINT}</u>, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
263     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
264     * </table></div>
265     */
266    public static final Unit<Length> POINT;
267
268    /**
269     * The SI derived unit for area (m²).
270     * The unlocalized name is “square metre”.
271     *
272     * <div class="note">
273     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
274     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
275     *   <tr><td>SI area units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u><b>{@code SQUARE_METRE}</b></u>, {@link #HECTARE}.</td></tr>
276     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #CUBIC_METRE}.</td></tr>
277     * </table></div>
278     */
279    public static final Unit<Area> SQUARE_METRE;
280
281    /**
282     * Unit of measurement defined as 10,000 square metres (1 ha).
283     * One hectare is exactly equals to one hectometre (1 hm²).
284     * While not an SI unit, the hectare is often used in the measurement of land.
285     * The unlocalized name is “hectare”.
286     *
287     * <div class="note">
288     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
289     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
290     *   <tr><td>SI area units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #SQUARE_METRE}</b>, <u>{@code HECTARE}</u>.</td></tr>
291     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #CUBIC_METRE}.</td></tr>
292     * </table></div>
293     */
294    public static final Unit<Area> HECTARE;
295
296    /**
297     * The SI derived unit for volume (m³).
298     * The unlocalized name is “cubic metre”.
299     */
300    public static final Unit<Volume> CUBIC_METRE;
301
302    /**
303     * The unit for litre volume (L, l or ℓ).
304     * The unlocalized name is “litre”.
305     */
306    public static final Unit<Volume> LITRE;
307
308    /**
309     * The SI unit for solid angles (sr).
310     * The unlocalized name is “steradian”.
311     */
312    public static final Unit<SolidAngle> STERADIAN;
313
314    /**
315     * Unit of measurement defined as 10<sup>-6</sup> radians (1 µrad).
316     * The distance of one microradian of latitude on Earth is approximately 2 millimetres.
317     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #RADIAN},
318     * the unlocalized name is “microradian” and the identifier is EPSG:9109.
319     *
320     * <div class="note">
321     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
322     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
323     *   <tr><td>SI angle units:</td>   <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code MICRORADIAN}</u>, <b>{@link #RADIAN}</b>.</td></tr>
324     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DEGREE}, {@link #ARC_MINUTE}, {@link #ARC_SECOND}, {@link #GRAD}.</td></tr>
325     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
326     * </table></div>
327     */
328    public static final Unit<Angle> MICRORADIAN;
329
330    /**
331     * The SI unit for plane angles (rad).
332     * There is 2π radians in a circle.
333     * The unlocalized name is “radian” and the identifier is EPSG:9101.
334     * This is the base of all other {@linkplain #isAngular(Unit) angular} units.
335     *
336     * <div class="note">
337     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
338     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
339     *   <tr><td>SI angle units:</td>   <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MICRORADIAN}, <u><b>{@code RADIAN}</b></u>.</td></tr>
340     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DEGREE}, {@link #ARC_MINUTE}, {@link #ARC_SECOND}, {@link #GRAD}.</td></tr>
341     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
342     * </table></div>
343     */
344    public static final Unit<Angle> RADIAN;
345
346    /**
347     * Unit of measurement defined as π/180 radians (1°).
348     * There is 360° in a circle.
349     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #RADIAN},
350     * the unlocalized name is “degree” and the identifier is EPSG:9102.
351     *
352     * <div class="note">
353     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
354     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
355     *   <tr><td>SI angle units:</td>   <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MICRORADIAN}, <b>{@link #RADIAN}</b>.</td></tr>
356     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code DEGREE}</u>, {@link #ARC_MINUTE}, {@link #ARC_SECOND}, {@link #GRAD}.</td></tr>
357     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
358     * </table></div>
359     */
360    public static final Unit<Angle> DEGREE;
361
362    /**
363     * Unit of measurement defined as 1/60 degree (1′).
364     * The distance of one arc-minute of latitude on Earth is approximately 1852 metres
365     * (one {@linkplain #NAUTICAL_MILE nautical mile}).
366     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #RADIAN},
367     * the unlocalized name is “arc-minute” and the identifier is EPSG:9103.

369     * <div class="note">
370     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">

373     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DEGREE}, <u>{@code ARC_MINUTE}</u>, {@link #ARC_SECOND}, {@link #GRAD}.</td></tr>
374     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
375     * </table></div>
376     */
377    public static final Unit<Angle> ARC_MINUTE;
378
379    /**
380     * Unit of measurement defined as 1/(60×60) degree (1″).
381     * The distance of one arc-second of latitude on Earth is approximately 31 metres.
382     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #RADIAN},
383     * the unlocalized name is “arc-second” and the identifier is EPSG:9104.
384     *
385     * <div class="note">
386     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
387     *   <caption>Related units</caption>

389     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DEGREE}, {@link #ARC_MINUTE}, <u>{@code ARC_SECOND}</u>, {@link #GRAD}.</td></tr>
390     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
391     * </table></div>
392     */
393    public static final Unit<Angle> ARC_SECOND;
394
395    /**
396     * Unit of measurement defined as π/200 radians (1 grad).
397     * There is 400 grads in a circle.
398     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #RADIAN},
399     * the unlocalized name is “grad”, but the “gon” alias is also accepted.
400     * The identifier is EPSG:9105.
401     *

407     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
408     * </table></div>
409     */
410    public static final Unit<Angle> GRAD;

412    /**
413     * Unit of measurement defined as 10<sup>-3</sup> seconds (1 ms).
414     * This unit is useful for inter-operability with various methods from the standard Java library.
415     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #SECOND}
416     * and the unlocalized name is “millisecond”.
417     *
418     * <div class="note">
419     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
420     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
421     *   <tr><td>SI time units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code MILLISECOND}</u>, <b>{@link #SECOND}</b>.</td></tr>
422     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MINUTE}, {@link #HOUR}, {@link #DAY}, {@link #WEEK}, {@link #TROPICAL_YEAR}.</td></tr>
423     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}, {@link #HERTZ}.</td></tr>
424     * </table></div>
425     *
426     * @see java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit#MILLISECONDS
427     */
428    public static final Unit<Time> MILLISECOND;
429
430    /**

440     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}, {@link #HERTZ}.</td></tr>
441     * </table></div>

505    /**
506     * Unit of measurement approximately equals to 365.24219 days (1 a).
507     * This is defined by the International Union of Geological Sciences (IUGS) as exactly 31556925.445 seconds,
508     * taken as the length of the tropical year in the the year 2000.
509     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #SECOND},
510     * the unlocalized name is “year” and the identifier is EPSG:1029.
511     *
512     * <div class="note">
513     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
514     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
515     *   <tr><td>SI time units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MILLISECOND}, <b>{@link #SECOND}</b>.</td></tr>
516     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MINUTE}, {@link #HOUR}, {@link #DAY}, {@link #WEEK}, <u>{@code TROPICAL_YEAR}</u>.</td></tr>
517     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}, {@link #HERTZ}.</td></tr>
518     * </table></div>
519     */
520    public static final Unit<Time> TROPICAL_YEAR;
521
522    /**
523     * The SI derived unit for frequency (Hz).
524     * One hertz is equal to one cycle per {@linkplain #SECOND second}.
525     * The unlocalized name is “hertz”.
526     *
527     * <div class="note">
528     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">

531     * </table></div>
532     */
533    public static final Unit<Frequency> HERTZ;
534
535    /**
536     * The SI derived unit for speed (m/s).
537     * The unlocalized name is “metres per second” and the identifier is EPSG:1026.
538     *
539     * <div class="note">
540     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
541     *   <caption>Related units</caption>

545     * </table></div>
546     */
547    public static final Unit<Speed> METRES_PER_SECOND;

549    /**
550     * Unit of measurement defined as 1/3.6 metres per second (1 km/h).
551     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}
552     * and the unlocalized name is “kilometres per hour”.
553     *
554     * <div class="note">
555     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
556     *   <caption>Related units</caption>

560     * </table></div>

562    public static final Unit<Speed> KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR;
563
564    /**
565     * The SI derived unit for pressure (Pa).
566     * One pascal is equal to 1 N/m².
567     * Pressures are often used for height measurements on a vertical axis.
568     * The unlocalized name is “pascal”.
569     *
570     * <div class="note">
571     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
572     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
573     *   <tr><td>SI pressure units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u><b>{@code PASCAL}</b></u>, {@link #HECTOPASCAL}.</td></tr>
574     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DECIBAR}, {@link #BAR}, {@link #ATMOSPHERE}.</td></tr>
575     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>        <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #NEWTON} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
576     * </table></div>
577     */
578    public static final Unit<Pressure> PASCAL;
579
580    /**
581     * Unit of measurement defined as 100 pascals (1 hPa).
582     * The hectopascal is the international unit for measuring atmospheric or barometric pressure
583     * and is exactly equal to one millibar.
584     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #PASCAL}
585     * and the unlocalized name is “hectopascal”.
586     *
587     * <div class="note">
588     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
589     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
590     *   <tr><td>SI pressure units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #PASCAL}</b>, <u>{@code HECTOPASCAL}</u>.</td></tr>
591     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DECIBAR}, {@link #BAR}, {@link #ATMOSPHERE}.</td></tr>
592     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>        <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #NEWTON} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
593     * </table></div>
594     */
595    public static final Unit<Pressure> HECTOPASCAL;
596
597    /**
598     * Unit of measurement defined as 10000 pascals (1 dbar).
599     * This unit is used in oceanography as there is an approximate numerical equivalence
600     * between pressure changes in decibars and depth changes in metres underwater.
601     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #PASCAL}
602     * and the unlocalized name is “decibar”.
603     *
604     * <div class="note">
605     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
606     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
607     *   <tr><td>SI pressure units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #PASCAL}</b>, {@link #HECTOPASCAL}.</td></tr>
608     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code DECIBAR}</u>, {@link #BAR}, {@link #ATMOSPHERE}.</td></tr>
609     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>        <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #NEWTON} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
610     * </table></div>
611     */
612    public static final Unit<Pressure> DECIBAR;
613
614    /**
615     * Unit of measurement defined as 100000 pascals (1 bar).
616     * One bar is slightly less than the average atmospheric pressure on Earth at sea level.
617     * One millibar is exactly equal to one {@linkplain #HECTOPASCAL hectopascal}.
618     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #PASCAL}
619     * and the unlocalized name is “bar”.
620     *
621     * <div class="note">
622     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
623     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
624     *   <tr><td>SI pressure units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #PASCAL}</b>, {@link #HECTOPASCAL}.</td></tr>
625     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DECIBAR}, <u>{@code BAR}</u>, {@link #ATMOSPHERE}.</td></tr>
626     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>        <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #NEWTON} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
627     * </table></div>
628     */
629    public static final Unit<Pressure> BAR;
630
631    /**
632     * Unit of measurement defined as 101325 pascals (1 atm).
633     * One atmosphere reflects the pressure at the mean sea level for countries around 49°N of latitude.
634     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #PASCAL}
635     * and the unlocalized name is “atmosphere”.
636     *
637     * <div class="note">
638     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
639     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
640     *   <tr><td>SI pressure units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #PASCAL}</b>, {@link #HECTOPASCAL}.</td></tr>
641     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DECIBAR}, {@link #BAR}, <u>{@code ATMOSPHERE}</u>.</td></tr>
642     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>        <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #NEWTON} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
643     * </table></div>
644     */
645    public static final Unit<Pressure> ATMOSPHERE;
646
647    /**
648     * The SI derived unit for force (N).
649     * One newton is the force required to give a mass of 1 kg an acceleration of 1 m/s².
650     * The unlocalized name is “newton”.
651     *
652     * <div class="note">
653     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
654     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
655     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #KILOGRAM} ⋅ {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND} ∕ {@link #SECOND}</td></tr>
656     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #PASCAL}, {@link #JOULE}, {@link #WATT}.</td></tr>
657     * </table></div>
658     */
659    public static final Unit<Force> NEWTON;
660
661    /**
662     * The SI derived unit for energy (J).
663     * The unlocalized name is “joule”.
664     *
665     * <div class="note">
666     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
667     *   <caption>Related units</caption>

670     * </table></div>
671     */
672    public static final Unit<Energy> JOULE;

674    /**
675     * The SI derived unit for power (W).
676     * One watt is equal to one joule per second.
677     * The unlocalized name is “watt”.

680     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">

683     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #VOLT}.</td></tr>
684     * </table></div>
685     */
686    public static final Unit<Power> WATT;
687
688    /**
689     * The SI derived unit for electric potential difference (V).
690     * The unlocalized name is “volt”.
691     *
692     * <div class="note">
693     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
694     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
695     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #WATT} ∕ {@link #AMPERE}</td></tr>
696     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #FARAD}, {@link #OHM}, {@link #SIEMENS}, {@link #WEBER}.</td></tr>
697     * </table></div>
698     */
699    public static final Unit<ElectricPotential> VOLT;

701    /**
702     * The SI base unit for electric current (A).
703     * The unlocalized name is “ampere”.
704     *

706     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
707     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
708     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #COULOMB}, {@link #VOLT}, {@link #OHM}, {@link #SIEMENS}, {@link #HENRY}.</td></tr>
709     * </table></div>
710     */
711    public static final Unit<ElectricCurrent> AMPERE;
712
713    /**
714     * The SI derived unit for electric charge (C).
715     * One coulomb is the charge transferred by a current of one ampere during one second.
716     * The unlocalized name is “coulomb”.
717     *
718     * <div class="note">
719     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
720     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
721     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #AMPERE} ⋅ {@link #SECOND}</td></tr>
722     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #FARAD}.</td></tr>
723     * </table></div>
724     */
725    public static final Unit<ElectricCharge> COULOMB;
726
727    /**
728     * The SI derived unit for electric capacitance (F).
729     * The unlocalized name is “farad”.
730     *
731     * <div class="note">
732     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
733     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
734     *   <tr><td>Components:</td> <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #COULOMB} ∕ {@link #VOLT}</td></tr>
735     * </table></div>
736     */
737    public static final Unit<ElectricCapacitance> FARAD;
738
739    /**
740     * The SI derived unit for electric resistance (Ω).
741     * This is the inverse of electric conductance.
742     * The unlocalized name is “ohm”.
743     *
744     * <div class="note">
745     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
746     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
747     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #VOLT} ∕ {@link #AMPERE}</td></tr>
748     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SIEMENS}.</td></tr>
749     * </table></div>
750     */
751    public static final Unit<ElectricResistance> OHM;
752
753    /**
754     * The SI derived unit for electric conductance (S).
755     * This is the inverse of electric resistance.
756     * The unlocalized name is “siemens”.
757     *
758     * <div class="note">
759     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
760     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
761     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #AMPERE} ∕ {@link #VOLT}</td></tr>
762     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #OHM}.</td></tr>
763     * </table></div>
764     */
765    public static final Unit<ElectricConductance> SIEMENS;
766
767    /**
768     * The SI derived unit for magnetic flux (Wb).
769     * The unlocalized name is “weber”.
770     *
771     * <div class="note">
772     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
773     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
774     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #VOLT} ⋅ {@link #SECOND}</td></tr>
775     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #TESLA}, {@link #HENRY}.</td></tr>
776     * </table></div>
777     */
778    public static final Unit<MagneticFlux> WEBER;
779
780    /**
781     * The SI derived unit for magnetic flux density (T).
782     * The unlocalized name is “tesla”.
783     *
784     * <div class="note">
785     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
786     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
787     *   <tr><td>Components:</td> <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #WEBER} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
788     * </table></div>
789     */
790    public static final Unit<MagneticFluxDensity> TESLA;
791
792    /**
793     * The SI derived unit for inductance (H).
794     * The unlocalized name is “henry”.
795     *
796     * <div class="note">
797     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
798     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
799     *   <tr><td>Components:</td> <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #WEBER} ∕ {@link #AMPERE}</td></tr>
800     * </table></div>
801     */
802    public static final Unit<ElectricInductance> HENRY;
803
804    /**
805     * The SI base unit for thermodynamic temperature (K).
806     * The unlocalized name is “kelvin”.
807     *
808     * <div class="note">
809     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
810     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
811     *   <tr><td>SI temperature units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u><b>{@code KELVIN}</b></u>.</td></tr>
812     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>     <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #CELSIUS}, {@link #FAHRENHEIT}.</td></tr>
813     * </table></div>
814     */
815    public static final Unit<Temperature> KELVIN;
816
817    /**
818     * Unit of measurement defined as the temperature in Kelvin minus 273.15.
819     * The symbol is °C and the unlocalized name is “Celsius”.
820     * Note that this is the only SI unit with an upper-case letter in its name.
821     *
822     * <div class="note">
823     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
824     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
825     *   <tr><td>SI temperature units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #KELVIN}</b>.</td></tr>
826     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>     <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code CELSIUS}</u>, {@link #FAHRENHEIT}.</td></tr>
827     * </table></div>
828     */
829    public static final Unit<Temperature> CELSIUS;
830
831    /**
832     * Unit of measurement defined as 1.8 degree Celsius plus 32.
833     * The symbol is °F and the unlocalized name is “Fahrenheit”
834     * (note the upper-case "F" letter).
835     *
836     * <div class="note">
837     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
838     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
839     *   <tr><td>SI temperature units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #KELVIN}</b>.</td></tr>
840     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>     <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #CELSIUS}, <u>{@code FAHRENHEIT}</u>.</td></tr>
841     * </table></div>
842     */
843    public static final Unit<Temperature> FAHRENHEIT;
844
845    /**
846     * The SI base unit for luminous intensity (cd).
847     * The unlocalized name is “candela”.
848     *
849     * <div class="note">
850     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
851     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
852     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #LUMEN}, {@link #LUX}.</td></tr>
853     * </table></div>
854     */
855    public static final Unit<LuminousIntensity> CANDELA;
856
857    /**
858     * The SI derived unit for luminous flux (lm).
859     * The unlocalized name is “lumen”.
860     *
861     * <div class="note">
862     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
863     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
864     *   <tr><td>Components:</td> <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #CANDELA} ⋅ {@link #STERADIAN}</td></tr>
865     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #LUX}.</td></tr>
866     * </table></div>
867     */
868    public static final Unit<LuminousFlux> LUMEN;
869
870    /**
871     * The SI derived unit for illuminance (lx).
872     * The unlocalized name is “lux”.
873     *
874     * <div class="note">
875     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
876     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
877     *   <tr><td>Components:</td> <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #LUX} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
878     * </table></div>
879     */
880    public static final Unit<Illuminance> LUX;
881
882    /**
883     * A SI conventional unit for mass (g).
884     * The unlocalized name is “gram”.
885     */
886    public static final Unit<Mass> GRAM;
887
888    /**
889     * The SI base unit for mass (kg).
890     * The unlocalized name is “kilogram”.
891     */
892    public static final Unit<Mass> KILOGRAM;
893
894    /**
895     * The SI base unit for amount of substance (mol).
896     * The unlocalized name is “mole”.
897     */
898    public static final Unit<AmountOfSubstance> MOLE;
899
900    /**
901     * The base dimensionless unit for scale measurements.
902     * The unlocalized name is “unity” and the identifier is EPSG:9201.
903     * This is the base of all other {@linkplain #isScale(Unit) scale} units:
904     *
905     * {@link #PERCENT} (%),
906     * {@link #PPM} (ppm) and
907     * {@link #PIXEL} (px)
908     * among others.
909     */
910    public static final Unit<Dimensionless> UNITY;
911
912    /**
913     * Dimensionless unit for percentages (%).
914     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #UNITY}
915     * and the unlocalized name is “percentage”.
916     *
917     * @see #UNITY
918     * @see #PPM
919     */
920    public static final Unit<Dimensionless> PERCENT;
921
922    /**
923     * Dimensionless unit for parts per million (ppm).
924     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #UNITY},
925     * the unlocalized name is “parts per million” and the identifier is EPSG:9202.
926     *
927     * @see #UNITY
928     * @see #PERCENT
929     */
930    public static final Unit<Dimensionless> PPM;
931
932    /**
933     * Sub-division of logarithm of ratio of the measured quantity to a reference quantity (dB).
934     */
935    public static final Unit<Dimensionless> DECIBEL;
936
937    /**
938     * Dimensionless unit for pixels (px).
939     * The unlocalized name is “pixel”.
940     * This unity should not be confused with {@link #POINT}, which is approximately equal to 1/72 of inch.
941     *
942     * @see #POINT
943     */
944    public static final Unit<Dimensionless> PIXEL;
945
946    /**
947     * Sets to {@code true} by the static initializer after the initialization has been completed.
948     * This is a safety against unexpected changes in the {@link UnitRegistry#HARD_CODED} map.
949     *
950     * <p>We use here a "lazy final initialization" pattern. We rely on the fact that this field is
951     * initialized to {@code true} only at the end of the following static initializer. All methods
952     * invoked in the static initializer will see the default value, which is {@code false}, until
953     * the initializer fully completed. While apparently dangerous, this behavior is actually documented
954     * in <a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-12.html#jls-12.4.1">section 12.4.1
955     * of Java language specification</a>:</p>
956     *
957     * <blockquote>The fact that initialization code is unrestricted allows examples to be constructed where
958     * the value of a class variable can be observed when it still has its initial default value, before its
959     * initializing expression is evaluated, but such examples are rare in practice. (…snip…) The full power
960     * of the Java programming language is available in these initializers; programmers must exercise some care.
961     * This power places an extra burden on code generators, but this burden would arise in any case because
962     * the Java programming language is concurrent.</blockquote>
963     */
964    static final boolean initialized;
965    static {
966        final UnitDimension length        = new UnitDimension('L');
967        final UnitDimension mass          = new UnitDimension('M');
968        final UnitDimension time          = new UnitDimension('T');
969        final UnitDimension current       = new UnitDimension('I');
970        final UnitDimension temperature   = new UnitDimension('Θ');
971        final UnitDimension amount        = new UnitDimension('N');
972        final UnitDimension luminous      = new UnitDimension('J');
973        final UnitDimension frequency     = time.pow(-1);
974        final UnitDimension area          = length.pow(2);
975        final UnitDimension speed         = length.divide(time);
976        final UnitDimension force         = mass.multiply(speed).divide(time);
977        final UnitDimension energy        = force.multiply(length);
978        final UnitDimension power         = energy.divide(time);
979        final UnitDimension charge        = current.multiply(time);
980        final UnitDimension potential     = power.divide(current);
981        final UnitDimension magneticFlux  = potential.multiply(time);
982        final UnitDimension pressure      = force.divide(area);
983        final UnitDimension dimensionless = UnitDimension.NONE;
984        /*
985         * Base, derived or alternate units that we need to reuse more than once in this static initializer.
986         */
987        final SystemUnit<Length>        m   = add(Length.class,        Scalar.Length::new,         length,        "m",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 9001);
988        final SystemUnit<Area>          m2  = add(Area.class,          Scalar.Area::new,           area,          "m²",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
989        final SystemUnit<Volume>        m3  = add(Volume.class,        Scalar.Volume::new,         length.pow(3), "m³",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
990        final SystemUnit<Time>          s   = add(Time.class,          Scalar.Time::new,           time,          "s",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 1040);
991        final SystemUnit<Temperature>   K   = add(Temperature.class,   Scalar.Temperature.FACTORY, temperature,   "K",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
992        final SystemUnit<Speed>         mps = add(Speed.class,         Scalar.Speed::new,          speed,         "m∕s", (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 1026);
993        final SystemUnit<Pressure>      Pa  = add(Pressure.class,      Scalar.Pressure::new,       pressure,      "Pa",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
994        final SystemUnit<Angle>         rad = add(Angle.class,         Scalar.Angle::new,          dimensionless, "rad", (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 9101);
995        final SystemUnit<Dimensionless> one = add(Dimensionless.class, Scalar.Dimensionless::new,  dimensionless, "",            SI,               (short) 9201);
996        final SystemUnit<Mass>          kg  = add(Mass.class,          Scalar.Mass::new,           mass,          "kg",          SI,               (short) 0);
997        /*
998         * All SI prefix to be used below, with additional converters to be used more than once.
999         */
1000        final LinearConverter nano  = Prefixes.converter('n');
1001        final LinearConverter micro = Prefixes.converter('µ');
1002        final LinearConverter milli = Prefixes.converter('m');
1003        final LinearConverter centi = Prefixes.converter('c');
1004        final LinearConverter hecto = Prefixes.converter('h');
1005        final LinearConverter kilo  = Prefixes.converter('k');
1006        final LinearConverter ten4  = LinearConverter.scale(10000, 1);
1007        /*
1008         * All Unit<Angle>.
1009         * 20 is the greatest common denominator between 180 and 200. The intent is to have arguments as small
1010         * as possible in the call to the scale(double, double) method, while keeping the right side integer.
1011         * Staying closer to zero during conversions helo to reduce rounding errors.
1012         */
1013        rad.related(4);
1014        RADIAN      = rad;
1015        GRAD        = add(rad, LinearConverter.scale(Math.PI / 20, 200       / 20), "grad", OTHER,    (short) 9105);
1016        DEGREE      = add(rad, LinearConverter.scale(Math.PI / 20, 180       / 20), "°",    ACCEPTED, (short) 9102);
1017        ARC_MINUTE  = add(rad, LinearConverter.scale(Math.PI / 20, 180*60    / 20), "′",    ACCEPTED, (short) 9103);
1018        ARC_SECOND  = add(rad, LinearConverter.scale(Math.PI / 20, 180*60*60 / 20), "″",    ACCEPTED, (short) 9104);
1019        MICRORADIAN = add(rad, micro,                                               "µrad", SI,       (short) 9109);
1020        /*
1021         * All Unit<Length>.
1022         */
1023        m.related(7);
1024        METRE          = m;
1025        NANOMETRE      = add(m, nano,                                     "nm",    SI,       (short) 0);
1026        MILLIMETRE     = add(m, milli,                                    "mm",    SI,       (short) 1025);
1027        CENTIMETRE     = add(m, centi,                                    "cm",    SI,       (short) 1033);
1028        KILOMETRE      = add(m, kilo,                                     "km",    SI,       (short) 9036);
1029        NAUTICAL_MILE  = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(   1852,        1), "M",     OTHER,    (short) 9030);
1030        STATUTE_MILE   = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(1609344,      100), "mi",    IMPERIAL, (short) 9093);
1031        US_SURVEY_FOOT = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(   1200,     3937), "ftUS",  OTHER,    (short) 9003);
1032        CLARKE_FOOT    = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(3047972654d, 1E10), "ftCla", OTHER,    (short) 9005);
1033        FOOT           = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(   3048,    10000), "ft",    IMPERIAL, (short) 9002);
1034        INCH           = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(    254,    10000), "in",    IMPERIAL, (short) 0);
1035        POINT          = add(m, LinearConverter.scale( 996264, 72000000), "pt",    OTHER,    (short) 0);
1036        /*
1037         * All Unit<Time>.
1038         */
1039        s.related(5);
1040        SECOND         = s;
1041        MILLISECOND    = add(s, milli,                                      "ms",  SI,       (short) 0);
1042        MINUTE         = add(s, LinearConverter.scale(         60,      1), "min", ACCEPTED, (short) 0);
1043        HOUR           = add(s, LinearConverter.scale(      60*60,      1), "h",   ACCEPTED, (short) 0);
1044        DAY            = add(s, LinearConverter.scale(   24*60*60,      1), "d",   ACCEPTED, (short) 0);
1045        WEEK           = add(s, LinearConverter.scale( 7*24*60*60,      1), "wk",  OTHER,    (short) 0);
1046        TROPICAL_YEAR  = add(s, LinearConverter.scale(31556925445.0, 1000), "a",   OTHER,    (short) 1029);
1047        /*
1048         * All Unit<Speed>.
1049         */
1050        mps.related(1);
1051        METRES_PER_SECOND   = mps;
1052        KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR = add(mps, LinearConverter.scale(10, 36), "km∕h", ACCEPTED, (short) 0);
1053        /*
1054         * All Unit<Pressure>.
1055         */
1056        Pa.related(3);
1057        PASCAL      = Pa;
1058        HECTOPASCAL = add(Pa,  hecto,                            "hPa",  SI,    (short) 0);
1059        DECIBAR     = add(Pa,  ten4,                             "dbar", OTHER, (short) 0);
1060        BAR         = add(Pa,  LinearConverter.scale(100000, 1), "bar",  OTHER, (short) 0);
1061        ATMOSPHERE  = add(Pa,  LinearConverter.scale(101325, 1), "atm",  OTHER, (short) 0);
1062        /*
1063         * All Unit<Temperature>.
1064         */
1065        K.related(2);
1066        KELVIN       = K;
1067        CELSIUS      = add(K, LinearConverter.offset(  27315, 100), "°C", SI,    (short) 0);
1068        FAHRENHEIT   = add(K, new LinearConverter(100, 45967, 180), "°F", OTHER, (short) 0);
1069        /*
1070         * Unit<Volume> and Unit<Mass>. Those units need to be handled in a special way because:
1071         * 1) The base unit of mass is "kg", not "g". This is handled by a hard-coded case in SystemUnit.
1072         * 2) The liter unit is not a SI units, but despite that is commonly used with SI prefixes.
1073         */
1074        SQUARE_METRE = m2;
1075        CUBIC_METRE  = m3;
1076        KILOGRAM     = kg;
1077        HECTARE      = add(m2, ten4,  "ha",        ACCEPTED,               (short) 0);
1078        LITRE        = add(m3, milli, "L", (byte) (ACCEPTED | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1079        GRAM         = add(kg, milli, "g", (byte) (ACCEPTED | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1080        /*
1081         * Force, energy, electricity, magnetism and other units.
1082         * Frequency must be defined after angular velocities.
1083         */
1084        HERTZ      = add(Frequency.class,           Scalar.Frequency::new, frequency,                    "Hz",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1085        NEWTON     = add(Force.class,               Scalar.Force::new,     force,                        "N",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1086        JOULE      = add(Energy.class,              Scalar.Energy::new,    energy,                       "J",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1087        WATT       = add(Power.class,               Scalar.Power::new,     power,                        "W",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1088        AMPERE     = add(ElectricCurrent.class,     null,                  current,                      "A",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1089        COULOMB    = add(ElectricCharge.class,      null,                  charge,                       "C",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1090        VOLT       = add(ElectricPotential.class,   null,                  potential,                    "V",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1091        FARAD      = add(ElectricCapacitance.class, null,                  charge.divide(potential),     "F",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1092        SIEMENS    = add(ElectricConductance.class, null,                  current.divide(potential),    "S",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1093        OHM        = add(ElectricResistance.class,  null,                  potential.divide(current),    "Ω",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1094        WEBER      = add(MagneticFlux.class,        null,                  magneticFlux,                 "Wb",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1095        TESLA      = add(MagneticFluxDensity.class, null,                  magneticFlux.divide(area),    "T",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1096        HENRY      = add(ElectricInductance.class,  null,                  magneticFlux.divide(current), "H",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1097        LUX        = add(Illuminance.class,         null,                  luminous.divide(area),        "lx",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1098        LUMEN      = add(LuminousFlux.class,        null,                  luminous,                     "lm",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1099        CANDELA    = add(LuminousIntensity.class,   null,                  luminous,                     "cd",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);    // Must be after Lumen.
1100        MOLE       = add(AmountOfSubstance.class,   null,                  amount,                       "mol", (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1101        STERADIAN  = add(SolidAngle.class,          null,                  dimensionless,                "sr",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1102        /*
1103         * All Unit<Dimensionless>.
1104         */
1105        ConventionalUnit<Dimensionless> bel;
1106        PIXEL   = add(Dimensionless.class, Scalar.Dimensionless::new, dimensionless, "px",    OTHER, (short) 0);
1107        PERCENT = add(one, centi,                                                    "%",     OTHER, (short) 0);
1108        PPM     = add(one, micro,                                                    "ppm",   OTHER, (short) 9202);
1109        bel     = add(one, PowerOf10.belToOne(), "B", (byte) (ACCEPTED | PREFIXABLE), (short) 0);
1110        DECIBEL = add(bel, Prefixes.converter('d'), "dB", ACCEPTED, (short) 0);
1111        UNITY   = UnitRegistry.init(one);  // Must be last in order to take precedence over all other units associated to UnitDimension.NONE.
1112
1113        UnitRegistry.alias(UNITY,       Short.valueOf((short) 9203));
1114        UnitRegistry.alias(DEGREE,      Short.valueOf((short) 9122));
1115        UnitRegistry.alias(ARC_MINUTE,  "'");
1116        UnitRegistry.alias(ARC_SECOND, "\"");
1117        UnitRegistry.alias(KELVIN,      "K");       // Ordinary "K" letter (not the dedicated Unicode character).
1118        UnitRegistry.alias(CELSIUS,     "℃");
1119        UnitRegistry.alias(CELSIUS,   "Cel");
1120        UnitRegistry.alias(FAHRENHEIT,  "℉");
1121        UnitRegistry.alias(GRAD,      "gon");
1122        UnitRegistry.alias(HECTARE,   "hm²");
1123        UnitRegistry.alias(LITRE,       "l");
1124        UnitRegistry.alias(LITRE,       "ℓ");
1125        UnitRegistry.alias(UNITY, SystemUnit.ONE);
1126
1127        initialized = true;
1128    }
1129
1130    /**
1131     * Invoked by {@code Units} static class initializer for registering SI base and derived units.
1132     * This method shall be invoked in a single thread by the {@code Units} class initializer only.
1133     *
1134     * @param  quantity   the type of quantity that uses this unit (should not be null).
1135     * @param  factory    the factory to use for creating quantities, or {@code null} if none.
1136     * @param  dimension  the unit dimension.
1137     * @param  symbol     the unit symbol, or {@code null} if this unit has no specific symbol.
1138     * @param  scope      {@link UnitRegistry#SI}, {@link UnitRegistry#ACCEPTED}, other constants or 0 if unknown.
1139     * @param  epsg       the EPSG code, or 0 if this unit has no EPSG code.
1140     */
1141    private static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> SystemUnit<Q> add(Class<Q> quantity, ScalarFactory<Q> factory,
1142            UnitDimension dimension, String symbol, byte scope, short epsg)
1143    {
1144        return UnitRegistry.init(new SystemUnit<>(quantity, dimension, symbol, scope, epsg, factory));
1145    }
1146
1147    /**
1148     * Invoked by {@code Units} static class initializer for registering SI conventional units.
1149     * This method shall be invoked in a single thread by the {@code Units} class initializer only.
1150     *
1151     * <p>The {@code target} argument should be an instance of {@link SystemUnit}.
1152     * The only exception is for creating the {@link #DECIBEL} unit base on the bel conventional unit.</p>
1153     *
1154     * <p>If the {@code target} unit holds a list of {@linkplain SystemUnit#related() related units}
1155     * (i.e. conventional units that can not be computed easily by appending a SI prefix), then the new
1156     * conventional unit is added to that list of related units. For example "foot" is related to "metre"
1157     * and "degree Celsius" is related to "Kelvin", but "kilometre" is not recorded as related to "metre"
1158     * because this relationship can be inferred automatically without the need of a {@code related} table.
1159     * The unrecorded units are all SI units related to {@code target} by a scale factor without offset.</p>
1160     */
1161    private static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> ConventionalUnit<Q> add(AbstractUnit<Q> target, UnitConverter toTarget, String symbol, byte scope, short epsg) {
1162        final ConventionalUnit<Q> unit = UnitRegistry.init(new ConventionalUnit<>(target, toTarget, symbol, scope, epsg));
1163        final ConventionalUnit<Q>[] related = target.related();
1164        if (related != null && (unit.scope != UnitRegistry.SI || !toTarget.isLinear())) {
1165            // Search first empty slot. This algorithm is inefficient, but the length of those arrays is small (<= 7).
1166            int i = 0;
1167            while (related[i] != null) i++;
1168            related[i] = unit;
1169        }
1170        return unit;
1171    }
1172
1173    /**
1174     * Returns the system unit for the given dimension, or {@code null} if none.
1175     * Note that this method can not distinguish the different kinds of dimensionless units.
1176     * If the symbol or the quantity type is known, use {@link #get(String)} or {@link #get(Class)} instead.
1177     *
1178     * <p><b>Implementation note:</b> this method must be defined in this {@code Units} class
1179     * in order to force a class initialization before use.</p>
1180     */
1181    static SystemUnit<?> get(final Dimension dim) {
1182        return (SystemUnit<?>) UnitRegistry.get(dim);
1183    }
1184
1185    /**
1186     * Returns the system unit for the given quantity, or {@code null} if none.
1187     *
1188     * <p><b>Implementation note:</b> this method must be defined in this {@code Units} class
1189     * in order to force a class initialization before use.</p>
1190     */
1191    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1192    static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> SystemUnit<Q> get(final Class<Q> type) {
1193        return (SystemUnit<Q>) UnitRegistry.get(type);
1194    }
1195
1196    /**
1197     * Returns the system unit for the given symbol, or {@code null} if none.
1198     * This method does not perform any parsing (prefix, exponents, <i>etc</i>).
1199     * It is only for getting one of the pre-defined constants, for example after deserialization.
1200     *
1201     * <p><b>Implementation note:</b> this method must be defined in this {@code Units} class
1202     * in order to force a class initialization before use.</p>
1203     *
1204     * @see Prefixes#getUnit(String)
1205     */
1206    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1207    static Unit<?> get(final String symbol) {
1208        return (Unit<?>) UnitRegistry.get(symbol);
1209    }

1211    /**
1212     * Do not allows instantiation of this class.
1213     */
1214    private Units() {
1215    }
