1217    /**
1218     * Returns {@code true} if the given unit is a linear unit.
1219     * Linear units are convertible to {@link #DEGREE}.
1220     *
1221     * <p>Angular units are dimensionless, which may be a cause of confusion with other
1222     * dimensionless units like {@link #UNITY} or {@link #PPM}. This method take care
1223     * of differentiating angular units from other dimensionless units.</p>
1224     *
1225     * @param  unit  the unit to check (may be {@code null}).
1226     * @return {@code true} if the given unit is non-null and angular.
1227     *
1228     * @see #ensureAngular(Unit)
1229     */
1230    public static boolean isAngular(final Unit<?> unit) {
1231        return (unit != null) && unit.getSystemUnit().equals(RADIAN);
1232    }
1233
1234    /**
1235     * Returns {@code true} if the given unit is a linear unit.
1236     * Linear units are convertible to {@link #METRE}.
1237     *
1238     * @param  unit  the unit to check (may be {@code null}).
1239     * @return {@code true} if the given unit is non-null and linear.
1240     *
1241     * @see #METRE
1242     * @see #ensureLinear(Unit)
1243     */
1244    public static boolean isLinear(final Unit<?> unit) {
1245        return (unit != null) && unit.getSystemUnit().equals(METRE);
1246    }
1247
1248    /**
1249     * Returns {@code true} if the given unit is a pressure unit.
1250     * Pressure units are convertible to {@link #PASCAL}.
1251     * Those units are sometime used instead of linear units for altitude measurements.
1252     *
1253     * @param  unit  the unit to check (may be {@code null}).
1254     * @return {@code true} if the given unit is non-null and a pressure unit.
1255     */
1256    public static boolean isPressure(final Unit<?> unit) {
1257        return (unit != null) && unit.getSystemUnit().equals(PASCAL);
1258    }
1259
1260    /**
1261     * Returns {@code true} if the given unit is a temporal unit.
1262     * Temporal units are convertible to {@link #SECOND}.
1263     *
1264     * @param  unit  the unit to check (may be {@code null}).
1265     * @return {@code true} if the given unit is non-null and temporal.
1266     *
1267     * @see #ensureTemporal(Unit)
1268     */
1269    public static boolean isTemporal(final Unit<?> unit) {
1270        return (unit != null) && unit.getSystemUnit().equals(SECOND);
1271    }
1272
1273    /**
1274     * Returns {@code true} if the given unit is a dimensionless scale unit.
1275     * This include {@link #UNITY} and {@link #PPM}.
1276     *
1277     * @param  unit  the unit to check (may be {@code null}).
1278     * @return {@code true} if the given unit is non-null and a dimensionless scale.
1279     *
1280     * @see #UNITY
1281     * @see #ensureScale(Unit)
1282     */
1283    public static boolean isScale(final Unit<?> unit) {
1284        return (unit != null) && unit.getSystemUnit().equals(UNITY);
1285    }
1286
1287    /**
1288     * Makes sure that the specified unit is either null or an angular unit.
1289     * This method is used for argument checks in constructors and setter methods.
1290     *
1291     * @param  unit  the unit to check, or {@code null} if none.
1292     * @return the given {@code unit} argument, which may be null.
1293     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code unit} is non-null and not an angular unit.
1294     *
1295     * @see #isAngular(Unit)
1296     */
1297    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1298    public static Unit<Angle> ensureAngular(final Unit<?> unit) throws IllegalArgumentException {
1299        if (unit != null && !isAngular(unit)) {
1300            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonAngularUnit_1, unit));
1301        }
1302        return (Unit<Angle>) unit;
1303    }
1304
1305    /**
1306     * Makes sure that the specified unit is either null or a linear unit.
1307     * This method is used for argument checks in constructors and setter methods.
1308     *
1309     * @param  unit  the unit to check, or {@code null} if none.
1310     * @return the given {@code unit} argument, which may be null.
1311     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code unit} is non-null and not a linear unit.
1312     *
1313     * @see #isLinear(Unit)
1314     */
1315    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1316    public static Unit<Length> ensureLinear(final Unit<?> unit) throws IllegalArgumentException {
1317        if (unit != null && !isLinear(unit)) {
1318            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonLinearUnit_1, unit));
1319        }
1320        return (Unit<Length>) unit;
1321    }
1322
1323    /**
1324     * Makes sure that the specified unit is either null or a temporal unit.
1325     * This method is used for argument checks in constructors and setter methods.
1326     *
1327     * @param  unit  the unit to check, or {@code null} if none.
1328     * @return the given {@code unit} argument, which may be null.
1329     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code unit} is non-null and not a temporal unit.
1330     *
1331     * @see #isTemporal(Unit)
1332     */
1333    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1334    public static Unit<Time> ensureTemporal(final Unit<?> unit) throws IllegalArgumentException {
1335        if (unit != null && !isTemporal(unit)) {
1336            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonTemporalUnit_1, unit));
1337        }
1338        return (Unit<Time>) unit;
1339    }
1340
1341    /**
1342     * Makes sure that the specified unit is either null or a scale unit.
1343     * This method is used for argument checks in constructors and setter methods.
1344     *
1345     * @param  unit  the unit to check, or {@code null} if none.
1346     * @return the given {@code unit} argument, which may be null.
1347     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code unit} is non-null and not a scale unit.
1348     *
1349     * @see #isScale(Unit)
1350     */
1351    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1352    public static Unit<Dimensionless> ensureScale(final Unit<?> unit) throws IllegalArgumentException {
1353        if (unit != null && !isScale(unit)) {
1354            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonScaleUnit_1, unit));
1355        }
1356        return (Unit<Dimensionless>) unit;
1357    }
1358
1359    /**
1360     * Multiplies the given unit by the given ratio. For example multiplying {@link #CENTIMETRE} by 254/100 gives
1361     * {@link #INCH}. Invoking this method is equivalent to invoking <code>{@linkplain Unit#multiply(double)
1362     * Unit.multiply}(numerator / denominator)</code> except that the use of a ration of integer values help
1363     * Seshat to improve accuracy when more than one arithmetic operation are chained.
1364     *
1365     * @param  <Q>          the quantity measured by the unit.
1366     * @param  unit         the unit to multiply.
1367     * @param  numerator    the numerator of the multiplication factor.
1368     * @param  denominator  the denominator of the multiplication factor.
1369     * @return the unit multiplied by the given factor.
1370     */
1371    public static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> Unit<Q> multiply(Unit<Q> unit, double numerator, double denominator) {
1372        return unit.transform(LinearConverter.scale(numerator, denominator));
1373    }
1374
1375    /**
1376     * Returns the factor by which to multiply the standard unit in order to get the given unit.
1377     * The "standard" unit is usually the SI unit on which the given unit is based, as given by
1378     * {@link Unit#getSystemUnit()}.
1379     *
1380     * <div class="note"><b>Example:</b>
1381     * if the given unit is {@link #KILOMETRE}, then this method returns 1000 since a measurement in kilometres
1382     * must be multiplied by 1000 in order to give the equivalent measurement in the "standard" units
1383     * (here {@link #METRE}).</div>
1384     *
1385     * If the given unit is {@code null} or if the conversion to the "standard" unit can not be expressed
1386     * by a single multiplication factor, then this method returns {@link Double#NaN}.
1387     *
1388     * @param  <Q>   the quantity measured by the unit, or {@code null}.
1389     * @param  unit  the unit for which we want the multiplication factor to standard unit, or {@code null}.
1390     * @return the factor by which to multiply a measurement in the given unit in order to get an equivalent
1391     *         measurement in the standard unit, or NaN if the conversion can not be expressed by a scale factor.
1392     */
1393    public static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> double toStandardUnit(final Unit<Q> unit) {
1394        return AbstractConverter.scale(unit == null ? null : unit.getConverterTo(unit.getSystemUnit()));
1395    }
1396
1397    /**
1398     * Creates a linear converter from the given scale and offset.
1399     *
1400     * @param  scale   the scale factor, or {@code null} if none (default value of 1).
1401     * @param  offset  the offset, or {@code null} if none (default value of 0).
1402     * @return a converter for the given scale and offset.
1403     */
1404    public static UnitConverter converter(final Number scale, final Number offset) {
1405        return LinearConverter.create(scale, offset);
1406    }
1407
1408    /**
1409     * Returns the coefficients of the given converter expressed as a polynomial equation.
1410     * This method returns the first of the following choices that apply:
1411     *
1412     * <ul>
1413     *   <li>If the given converter {@linkplain UnitConverter#isIdentity() is identity}, returns an empty array.</li>
1414     *   <li>If the given converter shifts the values without scaling them (for example the conversion from Kelvin to
1415     *       Celsius degrees), returns an array of length 1 containing only the offset.</li>
1416     *   <li>If the given converter scales the values (optionally in addition to shifting them), returns an array of
1417     *       length 2 containing the offset and scale factor, in that order.</li>
1418     * </ul>
1419     *
1420     * This method returns {@code null} if it can not get the polynomial equation coefficients from the given converter.
1421     *
1422     * @param  converter  the converter from which to get the coefficients of the polynomial equation, or {@code null}.
1423     * @return the polynomial equation coefficients (may be any length, including zero), or {@code null} if the given
1424     *         converter is {@code null} or if this method can not get the coefficients.
1425     */
1426    @SuppressWarnings("fallthrough")
1427    public static Number[] coefficients(final UnitConverter converter) {
1428        if (converter != null) {
1429            if (converter instanceof AbstractConverter) {
1430                return ((AbstractConverter) converter).coefficients();
1431            }
1432            if (converter.isIdentity()) {
1433                return new Number[0];
1434            }
1435            if (converter.isLinear()) {
1436                final double offset = converter.convert(0);  // Should be zero as per JSR-363 specification, but we are paranoiac.
1437                final double scale  = converter.convert(1) - offset;
1438                final Number[] c = new Number[(scale != 1) ? 2 : (offset != 0) ? 1 : 0];
1439                switch (c.length) {
1440                    case 2: c[1] = scale;       // Fall through
1441                    case 1: c[0] = offset;
1442                    case 0: break;
1443                }
1444                return c;
1445            }
1446        }
1447        return null;
1448    }
1449
1450    /**
1451     * Returns the derivative of the given converter at the given value,
1452     * or {@code NaN} if this method can not compute it.
1453     *
1454     * @param  converter  the converter for which we want the derivative at a given point, or {@code null}.
1455     * @param  value      the point at which to compute the derivative.
1456     * @return the derivative at the given point, or {@code NaN} if unknown.
1457     */
1458    public static double derivative(final UnitConverter converter, final double value) {
1459        return AbstractConverter.derivative(converter, value);
1460    }
1461
1462    /**
1463     * Parses the given symbol. Invoking this method is equivalent to invoking
1464     * {@link UnitFormat#parse(CharSequence)} on a shared locale-independent instance.
1465     * The list of symbols supported by this method is implementation-dependent
1466     * and may change in future Seshat versions.
1467     *
1468     * @param  uom  the symbol to parse, or {@code null}.
1469     * @return the parsed symbol, or {@code null} if {@code uom} was null.
1470     * @throws ParserException if the given symbol can not be parsed.
1471     *
1472     * @see UnitFormat#parse(CharSequence)
1473     */
1474    public static Unit<?> valueOf(String uom) throws ParserException {
1475        return (uom != null) ? UnitFormat.INSTANCE.parse(uom) : null;
1476    }
1477
1478    /**
1479     * Returns a hard-coded unit from an EPSG code. The {@code code} argument given to this method shall
1480     * be a code identifying a record in the {@code "Unit of Measure"} table of the EPSG geodetic dataset.
1481     * If this method does not recognize the given code, then it returns {@code null}.
1482     *
1483     * <p>The list of units recognized by this method is not exhaustive. This method recognizes
1484     * the base units declared in the {@code TARGET_UOM_CODE} column of the above-cited table,
1485     * and some frequently-used units. The list of recognized units may be updated in any future
1486     * version of Seshat. The currently recognized values are:</p>
1487     *
1488     * <table class="sis">
1489     *   <caption>EPSG codes for units</caption>
1490     *   <tr>
1491     *     <td><table class="compact">
1492     *       <caption>Angular units</caption>
1493     *       <tr><td style="width: 40px"><b>Code</b></td><td><b>Unit</b></td></tr>
1494     *       <tr><td>9101</td><td>radian</td></tr>
1495     *       <tr><td>9102</td><td>decimal degree</td></tr>
1496     *       <tr><td>9103</td><td>minute</td></tr>
1497     *       <tr><td>9104</td><td>second</td></tr>
1498     *       <tr><td>9105</td><td>grad</td></tr>
1499     *       <tr><td>9107</td><td>degree-minute-second</td></tr>
1500     *       <tr><td>9108</td><td>degree-minute-second</td></tr>
1501     *       <tr><td>9109</td><td>microradian</td></tr>
1502     *       <tr><td>9110</td><td>sexagesimal degree-minute-second</td></tr>
1503     *       <tr><td>9111</td><td>sexagesimal degree-minute</td></tr>
1504     *       <tr><td>9122</td><td>decimal degree</td></tr>
1505     *     </table></td>
1506     *     <td class="sep"><table class="compact">
1507     *       <caption>Linear units</caption>
1508     *       <tr><td style="width: 40px"><b>Code</b></td><td><b>Unit</b></td></tr>
1509     *       <tr><td>1025</td><td>millimetre</td></tr>
1510     *       <tr><td>1033</td><td>centimetre</td></tr>
1511     *       <tr><td>9001</td><td>metre</td></tr>
1512     *       <tr><td>9002</td><td>foot</td></tr>
1513     *       <tr><td>9003</td><td>US survey foot</td></tr>
1514     *       <tr><td>9030</td><td>nautical mile</td></tr>
1515     *       <tr><td>9036</td><td>kilometre</td></tr>
1516     *       <tr><td>9093</td><td>statute mile</td></tr>
1517     *     </table></td>
1518     *     <td class="sep"><table class="compact">
1519     *       <caption>Time units</caption>
1520     *       <tr><td style="width: 40px"><b>Code</b></td><td><b>Unit</b></td></tr>
1521     *       <tr><td>1029</td><td>year</td></tr>
1522     *       <tr><td>1040</td><td>second</td></tr>
1523     *     </table></td>
1524     *     <td class="sep"><table class="compact">
1525     *       <caption>Scale units</caption>
1526     *       <tr><td style="width: 40px"><b>Code</b></td><td><b>Unit</b></td></tr>
1527     *       <tr><td>9201</td><td>unity</td></tr>
1528     *       <tr><td>9202</td><td>parts per million</td></tr>
1529     *       <tr><td>9203</td><td>unity</td></tr>
1530     *     </table></td>
1531     *   </tr>
1532     * </table>
1533     *
1534     * <div class="note"><b>Note:</b>
1535     * EPSG uses code 9102 (<cite>degree</cite>) for prime meridian and coordinate operation parameters,
1536     * and code 9122 (<cite>degree (supplier to define representation)</cite>) for coordinate system axes.
1537     * But Seshat considers those two codes as synonymous.</div>
1538     *
1539     * @param  code  the EPSG code for a unit of measurement.
1540     * @return the unit, or {@code null} if the code is unrecognized.
1541     *
1542     * @since 1.1
1543     */
1544    public static Unit<?> valueOfEPSG(final int code) {
1545        /*
1546         * The switch for the SexagesimalConverter cases are needed since we did not put those units
1547         * in the UnitRegistry map for reducing a little bit class loading in the common cases where
1548         * those units are not needed.
1549         */
1550        switch (code) {
1551            case 9107: // Fall through
1552            case 9108: return SexagesimalConverter.DMS_SCALED;
1553            case 9110: return SexagesimalConverter.DMS;
1554            case 9111: return SexagesimalConverter.DM;
1555            default: {
1556                return (code > 0 && code <= Short.MAX_VALUE) ? (Unit<?>) UnitRegistry.get((short) code) : null;
1557            }
1558        }
1559    }
1560
1561    /**
1562     * Returns the EPSG code of the given units, or empty if unknown.
1563     * This method is the converse of {@link #valueOfEPSG(int)}.
1564     *
1565     * @param  unit  the unit for which to get the EPSG code.
1566     * @return the EPSG code of the given units, or empty if unknown.
1567     *
1568     * @since 1.1
1569     */
1570    public static OptionalInt getEpsgCode(Unit<?> unit) {
1571        if (unit != null) {
1572            if (!(unit instanceof AbstractUnit<?>)) {
1573                unit = get(unit.getSymbol());
1574                if (!(unit instanceof AbstractUnit<?>)) {
1575                    return OptionalInt.empty();
1576                }
1577            }
1578            short code = ((AbstractUnit<?>) unit).epsg;
1579            if (code != 0) {
1580                return OptionalInt.of(code);
1581            }
1582        }
1583        return OptionalInt.empty();
1584    }
1585}
